Detailed Description

The lowest-level representation of a file, device, or socket.

If is often used for wrapping an operating system "handle". Some I/O classes can be queried for the FileDescriptor they are operating on, and this descriptor can subsequently be used during the instantiation of another I/O class, so that the new object will reuse it.

The FileDescriptor class also contains static fields representing the system's standard input, output and error streams. These can be used directly if desired, but it is recommended to go through System.in, System.out, and System.err streams respectively.

Applications should not create new FileDescriptors.

The following example demonstrates how to use this FileDescriptor class.

 MyPage::onInit(Persistence* const savedInstanceState) {

     // new Content instance
     gaia::core::Context* context = new gaia::core::Context(this);

     gaia::base::String fileName("file.txt");
     gaia::storage::FileOutputStream* fos =
             context->openFileOutput(fileName, Context::MODE_WORLD_READABLE);

     gaia::base::ByteArray buffer(20);
     fos->write(buffer);

     gaia::storage::FileDescriptor* fd = fos->getFD();
     // Check the file descriptor whether it is valid or not.
     if (fd->valid()) {
         // Ensures that data which is buffered within the underlying
         // implementation is written out to the appropriate device before
         // returning.
         fd->sync();
     }
     fos->close();
 }

See the sample given above. It check the file descriptor whether it is valid and ensures that data which is buffered within the underlying implementation is written out to the appropriate device before returning.

See also:
FileInputStream::getFDN()
FileOutputStream::getFDN()
